content.body: hsivonen: Hey, your validator sploded on me
"Internal Error: Oops. That was not supposed to happen. A bug manifested itself in the application internals. Unable to continue. Sorry. The admin was notified."
well, that's weird
the "html5" twitter account quit working around end of September
wohay, someone finally noticed!
because I do not have it set up to do Oauth
you are the first person to notice
well, I noticed
well, second
i noticed when it broke
(it=the whatwg twitter stuff)
and didn't do anything about it because nobody complained
Hixie: yeah I mean the "html5" one -- I guess the whatwg one is the same thing
yup
i took it as a sign that twitter was pointless
I think I actually just copied your script when I set up the "html5" one
heh
amen
for this kind of stuff at least
all i've ever seen on twitter is people bitching
twitter is now my means for exploring languages I don't speak
it's useful for that at least
and I've switched to only tweeting in languages that I don't actually speak nor understand well yet
heh
encountered http://twitlonger.com/ today, which seems quite absurd
I figure, if I'm going to tweet, I might as well learn a little about it each tiem
Hixie: anyway, what I was saying was weird was that an "html5" tweet did just get posted
in spite of me doing nothing to "fix" the no-oauth "problem"
http://twitter.com/#!/html5/status/28355466520
um
odd
so, I don't know why that one went through
not that I care so much
just… odd
o_O
that _is_ odd
Philip`: the better way to twit longer is to use Chinese
maybe you heard me say this already, but if you tweet in English, it takes 2.5 to 3 times as much characters as when you tweet in Chinese
the better way to tweet longer is to use buzz
what's buzz? :)
Philip`: what does http://www.twitlonger.com/ actually do?
posts multiple tweets in serial?
It posts the first n characters of your message and then a link to a page that has the rest of it
ah
well, big whoop
site should then be called "howtotwitlongerforthetotallyclueless"
or something
but I guess that was your point
absure
absurd
dammit
always bears in mind the words of our now Prime Minister, "The trouble with Twitter, the instantness of it - too many twits might make a twat."
I almost always type "absure" instead of "absurd"
heh
did dude really say that?!
that is gold
http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8176194.stm
absurd is "hurt" in Welsh
järjetön
in Finnish
which doesn't quite meet my "easier to type" requirement
there's no really good recognizable cognate for "absurd"
except for "absurd" that is i
most European languages just seem to have some variation of "absurd" or "absurd" itself
I guess because it came from Latin
RIDICULARIUS
now, that's a great word
way better than just plan "ridiculous"
"surreal" is "swrrealaidd" in Welsh
even _looks_  surreal
Welsh is a trip
Google Translate gives "epätodellinen" for Finnish translation of "surreal"
which actually seems to be more like "unreal"
http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ep%C3%A4todellinen
epä- +‎ todellinen
epä- = "un-"
wonders if gsnedders speaks Scottish Gaelic at all
Wiktionary is a great source for examining translations for single words
e.g., http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/surreal
but you need to set the Visibility > Show translations option
http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/os-fh%C3%ACreach#Scottish_Gaelic
os-fhìreach = surreal
shuts up because he realizes that the odds of anybody else here caring to hear about this here are close to nil
afternoon all
hey robman
how's the weather in Australia?
misses it already
sunny and hot
nice
you back in japan?
yup
noice
at home but heading out for lunch soon
with a friend here who works for Mozilla
yum...have fun
so I got to schlep off to the other side of town
I wish they'd move their office somewhere more convenient for me :)
schlep is a word that's appearing in my life more and more nowadays
heh
well, that sounds bad
i was lugging way too many laptops and a tripod all over Seoul - I feel shorter now
ah yeah
how did that meeting go, btw?
the AR thing, right?
really productive
yah
very intereting bunch of people
ETRI people were there?
yos
and ogc
great
and khronos
etc
oh
Khronos is a big plus for sure
Neil was awesome...he really listened and engaged
great
wants to evangelise a common time system across all sensor related things to the khronos members
would be great for sensor fusion/etc
interesting
did WebGL come up at all?
aboslutely
neat
minutes available anywhere yet?
and he's really keen to work with the w3c folks on improving the composition model
yeah...holon
what would "improving the composition model" mean in practice, I wonder?
general notes here http://www.perey.com/ARStandardsMeetingOutputs.html and his notes here http://www.perey.com/ARStandards/Khronos_Standards_for_Mobile_AR.pdf
takes a gander
MikeSmith when you get a chance please checkout this too http://www.slideshare.net/robman/patterns-of-interest-iswar-seoul-2010
will do
i'd especially like to discuss slides 18-20 with you 8)
hai
man
this whole presentation looks pretty interesting actually
aw shux
I have personally been away from this stuff for a while
professionally I mean
I don't remember if I told you that before W3C I did work mostly for the mobile market
product dev
backend stuff
and client stuff
also
cool
i gotta run to a meeting...have a great lunch and lets chat later
boi
in your slides, what are "triggers"?
eh?
I don't know "boi" either
acronym?
sorry...that was bye
ill bbak later
k
I gotta go soon too
but wanted to say you might want to consider coming to the Internet of Things conference in Tokyo at the end of November
I helped out with review of some papers for that
wishes he could go to this conf, but can't go out of Canada before Jan
too bad for you karlcow
I hope you learned your lesson
living in Japan too long? :p
I meant how you tried to smuggle your crack pipe through customs
hehe. himitsu
i am amazed at how many parsers insecurely handle external xml entities
just found *another* bug in an RSS reader...
Hixie: maybe ie's way of dealing with <meta http-equiv=x-ua-compatible> is screwing you over in your navigation tests?
zcorpan: how so?
i mean, i don't have it set
and i don't see why what i'm testing would be relevant to that
surely it'll be the same in all the modes...
Hixie: i don't know how it works, but maybe ie is first parsing looking for the meta, and then reparsing if it didn't find one
i doubt it, that'd be a perf nightmare
also the timings don't fit that hypothesis (some of the tests have timestamps)
ok
(iirc ie reparses when turning on designMode, which is also perf nightmare but doesn't happen as often)
https://developer.mozilla.org/en/JavaScript_typed_arrays - does gecko support binary messages in websockets?
I don't think so
http://yfrog.com/f/2fejgrj/
old news
but still funny
jgraham, btw, I meant "WHATTF" last night
not sure about action man and bureaucracy man, but that sounds fun too :)
also, another day, still not published
Mike is still flying around?
That's superman
Although I guess Mike might hve an alter-ego
Would explain a lot
xml-stylesheet will be published 28th
as REC?
yeah
my first REC :)
with how many conforming implementations?
dunno
congrats anyway
I don't have any RECs
hmm validator.nu still doesn't validate xml-stylesheet
hsivonen: ^
seems like all tests in http://simon.html5.org/test/xml/xml-stylesheet/parsing/ give bogus errors in validator.nu
zcorpan: hmm. I wonder if MikeSmith landed the code...
zcorpan: the code is there
zcorpan: looks like the XML parser is doing something very bogus
zcorpan: I'm sorry. this XML parser is very, very sad
some day, I should write my own XML parser, with enough 5
did you switch xml parser at some point? it worked when mike was implementing xml-stylesheet
zcorpan: no, I think I haven't changed anything about the XML parser
ok. weird
whoa. "unless you cannot accept LGPL in your environment"
why on earth do the subclipse developers bother to maintain installation options for people who aren't OK with LGPL?
whoa! I just saw a signed Eclipse plug-in for the first time. Seemed to be a self-signed cert, though.
zcorpan: I haven't touched the XML parser since April 2009
zcorpan: are you sure you've tested without the XML declaration before?
zcorpan: the parser seems to be bogus
zcorpan: if the first four bytes are <?xm, it expects it to be the start of an XML declaration and it expect the XML declaration to be within the first 64 bytes
both expectations are thoroughly bogus, of course
hsivonen: i'm pretty sure i tested without xml decl. but maybe mike's setup injected an xml decl or something
http://arewefastyet.com/ interesting
I wonder how Opera compares
annevk: That seems quite simple to find out :)
wonders how numbers inside the browser compare to standalone shell numbers
Hixie, http://tantek.com/2010/294/t7/html5-whatwg-stopped-twitter-required-oauth
Hixie: P.Irish asked me to log here. Hello :)
hsivonen: if i add an xml decl, i still don't get the xml-stylesheet pi validated (no errors for a bogus pi)
252Fhtml%253E
wiki.whatwg.org times out for me
zcorpan: I think the data: URL you pasted isn't complete
Hixie: (Can't contact the database server: Lost connection to MySQL server at 'reading initial communication packet', system error: 110 (database.wiki.whatwg.org))
yeah, it got split to two messages
I wonder if there exists more of this stuff: http://www.aminutewithbrendan.com/pages/20101018
What stuff?
relatively short podcasts on browser stuff
aminutewithbrendan is full of it
(although it is javascript-oriented)
sure, I'm subscribed to that one and listen to most of it
crockford has a series of talks going on, but we can't call them short
So listening to those has given me an appreciation for one thing; if you set the volume on one <audio> element all other unplayed elements should start at the same volume by default. Or something
A UI issue of course
and not necessarily true
as it depends on the stream
would appreciate his browser not automaticall downloading many megabytes of data when loading the front page of that site, and instead waiting until he clicked 'play' on each <audio>
s//y/
The volume of one stream should not modify that of other streams on the same page, but it would be quite useful to have the browser remember the volumes of each stream
when we go back to that page later on.
I mean, it could be localStorage-ed, but that's something we inherently want for all media elements.
this XML parser is full of sadness
The problem is I start one, listen to it (at reduced volume) start another and have to reduce the volume again
Changing my system volume affects other applications
I could probably futz about with per-application volume controls but its a lot of complexity
and, on the web, the intrinsic loudness of different sound clips seems highly likely to change between pages
due to different recording and so on
But might be more constant on a single page
this total bogosity of the XML parser with <?xml-stylesheet hasn't come to my attention before
I guess most people use the XML declaration
jgraham: Seems like the OS's job to make per-application volume controls simple
(I think Vista does that already)
Philip`: In the case of the web it's not clear that will work, as I said
In any case I probably want per-tab volume controls
if we are doing it that way
zcorpan: http://html5.validator.nu/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Fsimon.html5.org%2Ftest%2Fxml%2Fxml-stylesheet%2Fparsing%2F001.xml
zcorpan: I hope the parser sucks less now when viewed as a black box. The source code got uglier.
It seems to me that when a piece of software is bad enough, patching it makes the code look even worse
Ælfred2 is so, so sad. Too bad it's not easy to notice on surface before it's too late.
hsivonen: cool, thanks
zcorpan: thanks for reporting
hsivonen: now the Show Source feature is broken instead :)
aargh
Dear lazyirc. I have a file with some lines in it. I want to provide each line of the file as the command line argument to a program. Is there some clever way to do that in the (bash) shell?
So if the file looks like
A
B
C
I want to run
foo A B C
where foo is the executable
Oh, maybe cat and backticks is enough if there are no special characters
And xargs is needed otherwise
Backticks make me sad
$() all the way
The shell makes me sad
Python
Pro tip: when disabling Bluetooth, do not disable wireless instead
perl -ne'`program "$_"`' lines.txt
Oh, I misread the question
In that case I suppose it's more like  perl -e'chomp(@_=<>); system("program", @_)' lines.txt  which will incidentally handle special characters in the lines
but that code doesn't use enough quote characters :-(
(Not enough to be pleasantly confusing, at least)
hsivonen: about the issue that Simon mentioned, I am not injecting an xml declaration or anything like that
but I can take a look later and see if i might be able to figure out what's wrong
maybe I am otherwise just doing something stupid in that code
wrong assumption or something
MikeSmith: your code isn't wrong
MikeSmith: the XML parser is wrong
ok
oh
well, that's not good
MikeSmith: are you sure you and Simon didn't test a W3C instance that runs the perl preprocessor on the input?
no
definitely not
well, I don't have an explanation why you haven't seen this before
whatever code I had running, it should still be running at http://www.w3.org/html/check
but the XML parser is definitely broken and has been unmodified for over a year
I see
MikeSmith: your instance shows the same bug
MikeSmith: http://www.w3.org/html/check?doc=http%3A%2F%2Fsimon.html5.org%2Ftest%2Fxml%2Fxml-stylesheet%2Fparsing%2F002.xml
well, that's weird
I'll have dinner and then I'll try to fix the XML parser again. more correctly this time hopefully
actually I was not running Simon's test from that side
I was using direct input
though I'm not planning on fixing it totally correctly
ok
it's too broken for that
MikeSmith: direct input doesn't sniff the bytes for encoding, so a different code path applies
ah
complained about lack of response http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-pfwg-comments/2010OctDec/0007.html
apparently my last email was end of August
http://code.google.com/p/html5lib/issues/detail?id=141 -> Could you guys take care of this? Or are you planning on dropping BeautifulSoup support altogether?
removes UTF-32 support from the XML side of Validator.nu
yay
the fight encoding proliferation front salutes you
annevk: did you notice the Gecko UTF-32 removal bug?
yup
zcorpan: http://html5.validator.nu/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Fsimon.html5.org%2Ftest%2Fxml%2Fxml-stylesheet%2Fparsing%2F002.xml&showsource=yes
now fixed for real, I hope
geez
gmail is getting so slow
it's annoying
maybe webapps are not it after all
constantly "still working" when I try to get through my labeled email
annevk: hsivonen using Zimbra
saucy is sähäkkä http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/s%C3%A4h%C3%A4kk%C3%A4#Finnish
comparative sähäkämpi, superlative sähäkin or sähäköin
abarth: b.m.o got another duplicate of http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=10427
abarth: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=605373
has WebKit gotten duplicates of this bug?
abarth: it might be worthwhile to check what exactly the old WebKit tree builder did
i don't think we've gotten reports of this
but the page is obviously broken in webkit now too
http://twitter.com/devongovett/status/28426814227 -- isn't it layout that's slow?
dromeo tests dom speed
testing layout speed is *hard*
it's probably a bad idea to publish a layout speed benchmark if bz hasn't reviewed it
So as of yesterday, looks like Firefox beats Chrome on Sunspider: http://arewefastyet.com/
Very slightly.
Awesome.  I just wish we had some more benchmarks up there, and Opera and IE9 were on them too.

People who say that javascript isn't slow are just making the wrong type of application. For a javascript game or audio analysis or image progessing or something, javascript speed is still a limiting factor
Of course for other types of application DOM is the limiting factor
But it is often pure scripting performance that limits the kind of applications that people are only just starting to write in javascript
How does JS compare to something like Java these days on standard useless programming benchmarks?
http://shootout.alioth.debian.org/u64/benchmark.php?test=all&lang=v8&lang2=java
regex is awesome with v8 :>
other than that java is typically 3-8 times faster
or even over 50 times faster if you do something js is very bad at :>
Hmm, so probably still room for improvement.
pidigits is horrible for v8.
garbage collection is probably one of those areas with some room for improvements
java's gc is very advanced
Interesting that memory is about the some.
same.
Possibly the implementation of pidigits for the v8 case is very bad
(possibly not of course)
http://arewefastyet.com/ <- seen that?
jm is now faster than v8 in sunspider
Needless to say these are not a good way to judge anything
jgraham, they're a decent heuristic.
Interesting.  It looks like Java doesn't perform much worse than C in time taken, at least for these programs -- median 2x slower -- but it's murdered on memory use.
AryehGregor: Well they probably have the advantage that language authors are unlikely to optimise for these benchmarks specifically
Yes.
But I think they are all very small problems compared to typical real applications
Performance in real applications is typically limited by bottlenecks, which are very small problems
Why don't they include PHP?  The site is even written in PHP.
Also would be cool to see different compilers compared.  ICC really murders GCC.
there is php on another machine
http://shootout.alioth.debian.org/u32/benchmark.php?test=all&lang=php&lang2=v8
Philip`: I don't know if that is really true. Sometimes you get quite flat performance profiles where you spend an equal amount of time everywhere
I mean if you are doing n-body simulations or something then sure it is all inner-loop dominated
the php version of reverse-complement is sorta silly... it does everything in native functions. there are like 4 functions chained together with do everything :>
*which
aho, well, that's sensible, isn't it?
well, it's sorta like having solveThisSpecificProblem function
you could say the same about the regex stuff though
It's fair to give languages credit for having good general-purpose tools like strtr and strrev and chunk_split.
just wanted to point out why php does surprisingly well in that particular benchmark .)
PHP has a mediocre standard library, but it's written entirely in C, so it deserves benchmark credit for that.
Hmm, I wonder if the problem with pidigits is the lack of a sensible long integer type in javascript
yea, emulating bigint stuff with doubles is sorta clumsy
but there is no way around that currently
well, there are ints in most js engines under the hood but there is some drag involved
bitops for example are always sorta slow
(i still use xorshift as prng though) :>
I think that is not true anymore since I think they are tested in sunspider :)
I would expect a loop containing bitops to be JITed to native instructions
jm was always pretty good at doing brainless math in a loop
it's pretty much the best case for tracing
eg 6 months ago mandelbrot stuff was about 3 times faster in jm than v8
either way, i love the js engine wars :)
(thanks google) :>
Thanks Mozilla too.
arewefastyet is great.

sees this in an EULA: "You may not, in whole or in part: copy, photocopy, reproduce, translate, reverse engineer (with the exception of specific circumstances where such act is permitted by law), derive source code, modify, disassemble, decompile, or create derivative works based on the Program; . . ."
Does that mean that the EULA is admitting that it's not prohibiting reverse-engineering except where it's already illegal anyway?
Hmm, maybe it only means "except in cases where the law doesn't let you sign away your right to reverse-engineer".  Or maybe it just means "we can sue you for breach of contract too if you do it".
Meh, who cares.
Arguably, it means that you are allowed to do so in any country that doesn't specify that reverse engineering is illegal.
What EULA is it?
Empire: Total War, a computer game.
Well, they do unusual EULA then.
Do they?  How so?
http://www.google.com/intl/en/jobs/joininggoogle/resume/index.html <-- HTML not an acceptable format?  Lame.
Although, iirc, Sun had a clause that forbid nuclear facilities from using their stuff.
Opera does
Also, flight control, IIRC
Fascinating.
Opera also accepts resumes in HTML form
just sayin'
I'd just have to move to Scandinavia, is that all?
It would be pretty sad if they didn't
Probably Google would too, but no sense in not following instructions.
Well I say "accepts" though for most technical jobs I mean "requires"
See, now that makes sense.
AryehGregor: Well not necessarily. But most jobs are in Scandinavia
And have someone manually inspect the source code and reject the application if they use <FONT COLOR="RED">.
None in, say, New York or Israel?
AryehGregor: http://www.opera.com/company/jobs/
So that's a no, then.
And you can infer what you like about the <font color> stuff from http://www.opera.com/company/jobs/opening/67/
"Your CV and covering letter should be in HTML5/CSS. That is your first test."
"Your CV and covering letter should be in HTML5/CSS. That is your first test."
Haha.
Awesome.
I also bet you get points off if you do -webkit-border-radius: 1em; -moz-border-radius: 1em
Well I'm not involved with recruitment
But I guess one would think twice before sending in something "Best Viewed with Google Chrome"
I just realized I have no idea how to write a decent resume.
You start with an indecent one and add clothes

AryehGregor: At least in the UK, there are certain cases where copyright law explicitly allows you to reverse-engineer programs (e.g. for interoperability) regardless of any other agreements that attempt to prohibit you from doing that
so I guess the agreements want to be clear that their terms should not be completely ignored, since they're still prohibiting all the other cases that aren't those certain cases
Oh, actually that's about "decompilation" rather than reverse-engineering
but close enough
MikeSmith: I have some vague idea about pronounciation, but that's the extent of my knowledge of Gaelic
ok
has some vague suspicion his CV was HTML 4.01 Strict
(But I can't remember)

AryehGregor: (If you wanted more useful CV advice possibly 'nobody cares about what you did at high school' and 'imagine you have to read 100 of them and want to find all the interesting stuff quickly' would be better)
Noted.
I guess my CV should clearly say "Okay, I'm just out of college, but I actually have lots of experience at this stuff as a volunteer."
AryehGregor: I think you should submit your CV as an animated movie created using xtranormal
makes sure to use goo.gl for his URL shortening, and makes a mental note to change that if he submits to anyone other than Google
AryehGregor: I'd say more, look at this experience, and hey, I went to college!
MikeSmith, I think that kind of resume is probably better suited to people applying for jobs as designers.
gsnedders: More like "hey I actually finished college" :p
AryehGregor: Having gone to college is unlikely to get you a job. Having experience is probably more important.
jgraham: Hey, I'm still at university, and went to all my lectures today!
(Turns out programming lectures are still ungodly boring)
(that isn't true I think)
(not about gsnedders lectures)
(but lots of people get jobs with degrees and little experience)
gsnedders, well, I don't think anyone is going to be fooled into thinking I have lots of professional experience at this point.
(having a degree *and* experience is obviously better)
I mean, I should come off as being much better than some average dude just out of college.
But probably not as good as someone with five years' of actual job experience.
(having just experience depends a lot on who you are applying to)
(except that if I'm applying specifically for web specs, probably like twelve people have at least five years' of job experience with that, so)
(half of them are probably in this room)

Yeah, sure. And my point about mentioning the experience first is more that you want to set yourself apart. Whoever is looking at it probably has 100 others to look at, all starting with, "I went to the university and got put in a box".
AryehGregor: To actually edit specs full time, or?
didn't get put into a box at university
although there was probably a societry for that if it's your thing
jgraham: Yes you did, you're the same as everyone else!
(There again, you'll probably claim I can't reference songs without girls around.)
(Again.)
AryehGregor: under the Entrepreneurial Experience heading, I recommend not listing any marijuana grow operations you might be running
MikeSmith, but if I'm doing something more unusual and enterprising, like smuggling cocaine, you think that would be a good thing to say?
gsnedders: (the irony of the song is that it is almost entirely the wrong way roungd, I think)
also, experience with making money trading smuggled contraband in country jail is often to valued quite a highly as you might think it would be
(I suspect people who go to university end up leading way more diverse lifestyles than people who don't)
jgraham: (Then there's the irony of who keeps singing it :P)
AryehGregor: just use code words
jgraham, it probably depends on how you measure diversity.
MikeSmith: Like when you say "Man mangement skills" and you mean "I'm a sociopath that will make CEO one day"
heh
MikeSmith, so do you think I should be aiming to make it into thedailywtf.com's next round-up of resume submissions, or what?
AryehGregor: Sure, it's all about getting your name known in the right circles

realizes that goo.gl provides public click profile data, so if he includes a goo.gl URL in a resume that he only submits to Google, he'll have a good idea of how many people read it and where they are.
The irony is delicious.
jgraham, sadly, TDWTF tends not to include names.
AryehGregor: Seriously though, what specifically are you trying to get a job doing?
AryehGregor: there's no such thing as bad publicity
You could just have your resume on your website and send yourself an email for every hit
(Like Hixie)

gsnedders, my general goal at this point is to get a job where people will pay me money.  Possibly this will involve me performing some activity they desire in exchange, preferably one that I find at least moderately enjoyable.
This seems like a fairly conventional course of action.

Ms2ger: If you do that, you should be very careful not to mention it in the presence of people who might then find it amusing to set up a script that downloads the page and loops several times a second
Realistically, something in web standards seems like a good bet, because there's hardly a lot of competition.  Failing that, programming is fine too.
So far it is not clear that you have excluded, say "high class male escort" from your list of possibilities
Well, I doubt that would be very competitive pay, given my skill set.
Also given my incredibly nerdy appearance.
Hey, I'm sure some are into that.
Maybe not enough for a regular income
hm, did anyone write a counter-proposal for the rel registry?
we're a few days past the deadline
TabAtkins said he was going to, but I don't know if he did anything yet
at the same time, the wg doesn't seem enthusiastic about the IETF registry
well, i sent a null CP
AryehGregor, we hired someone  who works from New York
AryehGregor, it depends on the position really, but we have several people working from home, including people working on the Core engine
works from home too
mostly
works from home
